Soil Notes: Soil classification done by Turner: mainly Paleudults; underlying geology is the Pebas formation
Natural disturbance notes: infrequent inundation/flooding may have a strong impact on forest dynamics;

Forest Description: Dominants include Fagus lucida and Cyclobalanopsis multinervis

Natural disturbance notes: wild boar-destructive

Soil Notes: parent rock beneath the plateau is anandesite flow; soils under most of the plot are well-weathered kaolinitic Oxisols with low cation exchange capacity; Soil classification done by Turner. thereëês been extensive classification work done on BCI in general (Baillie et al. 2007 _ online).
Natural disturbance notes: BCI is outside the hurricane belt, although local windstorms sometimes fell a hectare or more of forest, return time of such windstorms is between one and five thousand years; once every decade or two, an El Ni_o decreases rainfall during the rainy season and the following dry season is unusually severe;
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: the 50-ha Plot has been continuously forested for at least 1000 years; In pre-Columbian times, there were two small camps _ both over 600 years old _ on the site of the 50-ha plot, but there is no evidence of agriculture or forest clearing; 2 ha of the 50-ha plot was cleared by settlers for farms during the 19th century; Disconnected from contiguous forest upon creation of Panama Canal (habitat fragmentation)

Forest Description: _tropical evergreen broad-leaved forest mixed with conifers

Publication(s) describing site/plot: Lum et al., 2004; LaFrankie et al., 2005
Species & Number of trees notes: Values are for primary 2- ha plot only.
Forest Description: Mixed dipterocarp forest, including both primary and secondary plots. Primary forest is coastal hill dipterocarp forest.
Soil Notes: Fine, kaolinitic, isohyperthermic, Typic Kanhapludult
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: Severely fragmented; core primary forest area ca. 50 ha in good condition; fauna dramatically altered;

Forest Description: mixed broad-leaf Korean pine forest; Floristic characteristics of the community belong to Changbaishan flora, including some Tertiary relic species and subtropical species.
Soil Notes: The soil is classified as dark brown forest soil, and the pH values range from 4.13 to 7.13, with a mean of 5.45 (slightly acid). Ben: soils are likely to be Alfisols
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: logging in the area stopped about 180 years ago; the reserve is well protected, but is still affected NTFP collection;

Forest Description: Mature secondary forest (~80-120 years old).
Soil Notes: Ben: The soils are on basalt and appear to be Oxisols/Inceptisols.

Forest Description: Mixed dipterocarp forest
Natural disturbance notes: Occasional severe El Nino driven droughts; recent(?) increase in elephant activity;

Forest Description: dahurian larch
Castanopsis chinensis, Schima superba, and Engelhardtia roxburghiana are the three most dominant species in the upper layer.
mountain evergreen forest
Soil Notes: coarse, sandy, and well-drained,
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: Hunting and non-timber plant extraction

Forest Description: Quercus wutaishanica, Betula dahurica, and Acer mono are the three most dominant canopy species.
Dominated by Lauraceae an Fagaceae.
Soil Notes: extremely acidics
Natural disturbance notes: typhoons disturbance
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: Botanical garden is very well protected;

Publication(s) describing site/plot: Lai et al., 2009; Ma et al., 2009; Lin et al., 2012
Natural disturbance notes: ice storms occasionally causes stem breakage and tree falls

Plot Area & Dimensions notes: Plot is not exactly rectangular: one edge borders a lake.
Forest Description: Haliburton Forest belongs to the Great Lakes-St Lawrence Forest Region, which extends inland from the St Lawrence River across the Great Lakes into southeastern Manitoba and is characterized by a mix of coniferous and deciduous species. The most abundant species is sugar maple, which dominates the forest away from the shoreline. Many species show strong habitat specificity, with red oak, American ash, and ironwood on dry rocky hillslopes, American beech patchily distributed in highland upland sites, and eastern hemlock, red maple, and white pine near the lakeshore.
Mature secondary Eastern mixed deciduous forest dominated by eastern hemlock and northern hardwood species
Oak-laurel rain forest; The five most abundant species in the plot are Cryptocarya concinna,Neolitsea phanerophlebia, Litsea acuminate, Itea chinensis and Xanthophyllum hainanense.

Plot Area & Dimensions notes: dimensions are for 20-ha plot. There is also a 1ha plot.
Species & Number of trees notes: Value is for original 1 ha plot only; species count in progress
Forest Description: Secondary oak-laurel forest.  relatively young (50-60 year old)
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: There is a very long history of human impact on this forest; cleared in 19??, some areas planted with forest tree species; protected since 19xx?; has lost most of the important seed dispersing vertebrates

Forest Description: Seasonal dry evergreen, mixed deciduous, mixed dipterocarpus
Soil Notes: Conflicting info on soils here-- (1) Losos & Leigh says Oxisols, Inceptisols on p. 57; Ultisols in the back; (2) highly weathered Ultisols derived from a parent material of granite porphyry; soil textures are sandy loam in the surface horizon and sandy clay-loam in the subsurface horizon; fertile. Soil classification done by Baillie, who also suggested Mollisols, but this is not clear at the moment.
Natural disturbance notes: main natural disturbances are fire and drought
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: In a large complex of National Parks; very well protected; fauna fully intact;  occasional hunting;

Forest Description: Tall restinga; coastal "heath"
Soil Notes: the soils in the plot have a high content of fine sand and are unconsolidated; higher elevation areas (5-7 m a.s.l.) are well-drained, but may occasionally be flooded for short periods during heavy rains, these areas are associated with a thicker and darker podsol layer and are the older and more weathered marine deposits in the region (ca. 5000 years b.p.), the lower elevations (ca. 3 m a.s.l.), have the youngest soils (ca. 1600 y.b.p.), and the lack a podsol layer;  The plotëês hydromorphic podzol soils are the result of recent sea sedimentation and are characterized by high levels of sand, low levels of clay and silt, and low fertility. Nutrient-poor and water-stressed sandy soils.

Location & Elevation notes: Ituri has four plots at two locations (Edoro and Lenda). Geographic coordinates are the midpoint value. Individual coordinates are as follows: Edoro 1 (1.5614, 28.5152); Edoro 2 (1.5614,28.5241); Lenda 1 (1.3166, 28.6455); Lenda 2 (1.3079,28.6454).
Plot Area & Dimensions notes: Plot dimensions are listed in the following order: Edoro 1; Edoro 2; Lenda 1; Lenda 2.
Forest Description: Two of the 10-ha plots are in mixed evergreen forest (at Edoro) and two are in monodominant mbau stands (Lenda).
Natural disturbance notes: windstorms; elephants; minor role of fire
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: Almost pristine. Massive expansive of intact forest. Some very limited hunting pressure.

Location & Elevation notes: The difference in elevation between two stakes can be 20-50 m due to sharply undulating nature of karst terrain. As a result, the current topographical map with a contour internal of 10m is not detailed enough to show the real surficial features of the terrain.
Publication(s) describing site/plot: Lin et al., 2011; Wu et al., 2011
Species & Number of trees notes: lost species over first two censuses
Forest Description: Limestone forest dominated by Bischofia javanica and Figs; dominated by Ebenaceae, Euphorbiaceae and Moraceae specie
Soil Notes: limestone

Forest Description: dipterocarp dominated; includes ridge forest dominated by massive Dipterocarpus costatus trees
Soil Notes: soil classification done by Baillie
Natural disturbance notes: natural disturbances are limited to occasional strong wind storms, and probably rare but sever line squalls that have the potential to remove small stands of trees; the plot is on very steep terrain and there is some evidence that landslides may occasionally occur
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: the forest is adjacent to areas of heavy human habitation and hunting pressure is intense

Publication(s) describing site/plot: Thomas et al., 2003, 2015; Chuyong et al., 2004
Soil Notes: soils tend to be skeletal, sandy near surface, very nutrient-poor
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: National Park includes a big patch of intact forest; hunting pressure moderate to severe

Species & Number of trees notes: Species & stem count reported at 2015 CTFS workshop
Forest Description: Mixed dipterocarp forest
Soil Notes: The geology consists of sedimentary rocks predominantly of shales of the Setap Formation; on ridge tops and summits, the shale is overlain by the Meligan formation; Soils are silty clay dominated by quartz and kaolinite, also high in iron and aluminium oxides but extremely low in plant nutrients (N & P) and basic nutrients (Ca, Mg); moderately fertile compared to Lambir and Pasoh
Natural disturbance notes: A very stable climate, without major storm or natural disturbances; landslides on the the very steep terrain of the plot are fairly common;
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: apart from a limited amount of hunting and NTFP extraction in the National Park, there is little human impact in the forest; I include here hunting but not sure to what degree since the information was only obtained from local Ibans living near the area.

Soil Notes: acidic Andisols developed from volcanic ash; Soil texture is mainly sandy; the parent material is covered by diabases, gabbros and basalts belong to the Diabasic Group (Kvs), originated approximately in the upper Cretaceous;
Natural disturbance notes: small-scale windthrows are the most important natural disturbance; the forest is primary,
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: some areas were cleared for cattle ranching within the Park; harvest of palmito (Prestoea acuminata), the edible heart of palm is extracted by humans in July and December;

Forest Description: Mixed dipterocarp forest
Soil Notes: 2 types within plot, sandy and clay Ultisols. Soil classification done by Turner & Baillie.
Natural disturbance notes: El Nino affect seedling regeneration and tree mortality
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: 100m from edge with large paved road, has never been logged, but forest heavily impacted by hunting during the 1990s and early 2000s causing the extinction of some primate seed dispersers (gibbons), but more recent camera trapping has found high occupancy of muntjac, mouse deer, and short-tailed macaque, medium occupancy of other species (e.g. bearded pig).

Forest Description: The canopy is dominated by koa (Acacia koa) and ëêohiëêa (Metrosideros polymorpha), with a well-developed subcanopy of tree ferns (Cibotium species). Sub-canopy tree species include the following commonly observed species: olapa (Cheirodendron trigynum ssp. trigynum), kawaëêu (Ilex anomala), kolea (Myrsine lessertiana), and pilo (Coprosma rhynchocarpa).

Publication(s) describing site/plot: Lin et al., 2011; Chang et al., 2012
Forest Description: Lauro-Fagaceous Forest( following Su 1984).
Soil Notes: Geology is Tertiary Eocene Paileng formation of the Oligocene(?); substrate consists of argillaceous sandstone and shale; 2 soil types Typic Dystrochrept and Typic Hapleudult Red soils;
Natural disturbance notes: On average 0.7 typhoons pass through the plot each year. Typhoons result is soil saturation and because the slopes very steep there are frequent landslides;
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: There is a history of aboriginal hunting which was stopped in 19xx??

Forest Description: Oak-hickory dominated with major proportions of chestnut oak (Quercus prinus), white oak (Quercus alba), various other oak species (Quercus spp.) and assorted hickories (Carya spp.), while the understory is mainly sugar maple (Acer saccharum).

Publication(s) describing site/plot: Thompson et al., 2002; Thompson et al., 2004
Forest Description: tabonuco forest; named after the dominant tree (Dacryodes excelsa Vahl; Burseraceae)
Soil Notes: Soils were formed in residual volcanic ash that fell in the ocean to form volcani-clastic sandstones and siltstones, which were subsequently uplifted; Soils are dominated by old, deeply weathered kaolinitic Oxisols (Zarzal) and Ultisols (Cristal), and young, less-developed Entisols (Coloso and Fluvaquents) and Inceptisols (Prieto) in stream channels. Zarzal, Cristal and Prieto are deep clay soils, while Coloso and Fluvaquents are formed from alluvium in the stream channels. Soil classification done by Turner and others.
Natural disturbance notes: average return interval of severe hurricanes to the area is 50-60 years, but the forest has been damaged by severe hurricanes in both 1989 (Hugo) and 1998 (Georges); Landslides affect on average 1% of the forest area at any time and are mainly related to heavy rainfall events;
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: LFDP has been covered by forest since the 1930ëês; Before then, 1.16 ha of the 16-ha plot was farmed; 9.6 ha was variably clearcut, then allowed to regrow but planted in places with coffee or fruit trees; and 5.24 ha has always been in forest but was selectively logged; a small area (320 m2) was clearcut in the 1960ëês as part of an experiment; the introduction of the black rat and mongoose to the forest is an indirect form of human disturbance.

Species & Number of trees notes: Species count tentative/ in progress as of 2014.
Soil Notes: should be Oxisols plus whatever it is they have near the river (but safe to give the main soil _ Ox). Havenëêt been to the plot though so not certain.- BT
Natural disturbance notes: localized wind storms result in small canopy gaps;
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: the plot sits in one of the primary forest patches of the Biological Dynamics of Forest Fragments Project; hunting pressure due to network of unpaved roads;

Publication(s) describing site/plot: Brockelman et al., 2011; Chanthorn et al., 2013
Soil Notes: Soils are mostly well-drained brown or grey-brown, fine-sandy or silty-clay-loam; derived from residuum or colluvium of shale or sandstone; they are classified as isohyperthermic Ultic Haplustalf.
Natural disturbance notes: fire is not known for the plot for at least 30 years; strong wind storms may impact forest stands; the forest does appear to be late successional, but not clear what caused that.
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: there is no sign of logging or other human activities in the plot, with the exception of a few quadrats that were part of a larger agricultural clearing on one side of the plot;

Plot Area & Dimensions notes: Original plot was 3000 x 500; need updated dimensions
Forest Description: Acacia savanna. The vegetation is dominated by legumes, particularly of the genus Acacia. The abundant trees are Acacia drepanolobium, A. nilotica, A. mellifera. Scattered individuals of Combretum molle and Boscia sp. are also present.
Soil Notes: black cotton; intermediate; red soil. Soil classification done by Turner: might give the geology associated with the two soils _ the Vertisols are formed on Miocene lava flows, while the Alfisols are formed on the Precambrian basement geology.
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: mixed cattle ranching and wildlife reserve; invasive plant species;

Forest Description: Seasonal semi-evergreen lowland forest
Soil Notes: Udic Haplustalf Alfisols, dark brown to deep black clayey skeletal soils; fertile;
Natural disturbance notes: the main natural disturbance is fire; also, elephant browsing
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: a long history of selective timber extraction ended in the 1980s; hunting pressure was high and now low; ; invasive species abundant in the understorey; fauna is intact

Plot Area & Dimensions notes: he original plot measured 3 ha (300m x 100m) and was enlarged to 5.88 ha in 1997.
Species & Number of trees notes: Values are for original 3 ha plot only.
Soil Notes: acidic Paleudults or Hapludalfs with advanced weathering
Natural disturbance notes: the forest is strongly affected by monsoonal climate with consistent strong winds, and frequent typhoons
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: the plot is in a well-protected park with limited human impacts

Forest Description: Praire-forest ecotone. The forest occurs in moist, cool, spring-fed canyons leading to the Niobrara River that offer a stark contrast to the dry, well drained adjacent sand hills prairie.

Forest composition is principally Cleistanthus sumantranus, Sterculia monosperma, Vitex kwangsiensis, Hydnocarpus hainanensis, Diplodiscus trichosperma, antidesma japonicum, Excentrodendron tonkinense, Memecylon scutellatum, Ficus hispida, and Garcinia paucinervis.
Soil Notes: karst; limestone derived

Forest Description: Dominated by lama (Diospyros sandwicensis), alaheëêe (Psydrax odorata), and sandalwood (Santalum paniculatum), with few invasive plants in the understory.
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: near pristine condition (has probably never seen a major disturbance)

Forest Description: Mixed dipterocarp forest.
Natural disturbance notes: strong typhoons
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: the forest has never been logged, but human impacts include some hunting, some rattan collection, and a few high-value trees have been cut in the area of the plot

Forest Description: Mixed dipterocarp forest (red meranti-keruing lowland dipterocarp)
Soil Notes: the plot is on a relatively flat plain of Pleistocene alluvium, interspersed with a series of low hills of Triassic sediments and granite; the soils are predominantly well-drained Ultisols derived shale or granite and vary from clay-rich to quite sandy across the plot. Soil classification done by Turner & Baillie.
Natural disturbance notes: being in the equtorial tropics Pasoh is not exposed to large scale natural disturbances, though wind squalls can sometimes upend groups of trees
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: the Reserve is surrounded by logging concessions and oil palm plantations; hunting and NTFP extraction at low intensity

Soil Notes: Thibault et al., (1994) characterized the soil of area close to Rabi as ferralitic  and hydromorphic soil with mostly sandy clay (more or less 25% argile) to clay sand (more or less 35% argile). Thibault Marc, Fisher Brian L. and Goodman Steven M. (1994) Description of Monts, Doudou, Gabon and the 2000 Biodiversity inventory of the reserve. Pp. 3-15 in: Fisher, B.L., ed., Monts Doudou, Gabon: A floral and Faunal Inventory with reference to elavational variation. Number 28, Memoire of the California Academy of Sciences, San Francisco, CA.
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: Selective logging in the 1920's; seismic exploration in 1980's; well protected inside Shell concession

Soil Notes: Ben: Very fine, kaolinitic, isohyperthermic, Typic Hapludox
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: The Sherman plot has apparently been free of severe disturbance for 200 y or more, since the largest trees are of slow-growing species (Manilkara bidentata, Brosimum utile). But there are signs of human impact in the area - the largest Manilkara in the plot has been slashed many times for latex, and the northern hectare of the plot was obviously cleared recently.

Species & Number of trees notes: Stem count tentative, in progress as of 2014.
Forest Description: The four dominant species are Douglas Fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii), Coast Live Oak (Quercus agrifolia), Shreve's Oak (Quercus parvula var. shrevei) and Tanoak (Lithocarpus densiflorus); Fagaceae and Pinanceae together comprise three-fourths of all stems.
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: recreation as current local disturbance

Species & Number of trees notes: Tentative numbers; in progress as of 2014.
Natural disturbance notes: The biggest disturbance by far is climate warming induced permafrost thaw. See Baltzer et al. (2014) Global Change Biology 20: 824-834. This is resulting in rapid net forest loss.

Forest Description: Mixed dipterocarp forest.
Soil Notes: the plot is on metamorphic rocks of the Precambrian Age Highland Series; siliceous charnokite forms the prominent parallel crests; khondalite, rich in hornblende, underlies the fertile lower slopes and valleys; the soils overlying them are Humult to Udult Ultisols;
Natural disturbance notes: natural disturbances are limited to occasional strong wind storms
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: the Reserve has been impacted by selective logging in the 1970's, but not in the plot; extraction of NTFPs occurs on the margins of the forest

Forest Description: Mature secondary Eastern mixed deciduous forest; Liriodendron/Carya/Quercus species dominate. Typical mature secondary eastern mixed deciduous forest, with a canopy dominated by tulip poplar (Liriodendron tulipifera), hickories (Carya spp.), oaks (Quercus spp.) and white ash (Fraxinus americana), and an understory composed mainly of spicebush (Lindera benzoin), paw-paw (Asimina triloba), American hornbeam (Carpinus caroliniana) and eastern redbud (Cercis canadensis). It is classified as Upper Piedmont/Northern Blue Ridge Basic Mesic Hardwood Forest in the U.S. National Vegetation Classification system (USNVC code CEGL006186).
Soil Notes: Soil classification done by Turner.

Forest Description: Mature secondary Eastern mixed deciduous forest.Upland forest bisected with a section of floodplain forests, both around 120 years since initiation. The upland forest is an example of the _tulip poplarÕå association with an overstory dominated by tulip poplar (Liriodendron tulipifera), several oaks (Quercus spp.), beech (Fagus grandifolia), and several hickories (Carya spp.); a mid-canopy of red maple (Acer rubrum) and sour gum (Nyssa sylvatica); and an understory composed of American hornbeam (Carpinus caroliniana), spicebush (Lindera benzoin), and paw-paw (Asimina triloba). The flood plain forest is dominated by ashes (Fraxinus spp.), sycamore (Platanus occidentalis), and American elm (Ulmus americana).  Installation of the plot began in September 2007.
Soil Notes: Soil classification done by Turner: _ Ultisols (Hapludults) plus some Inceptisols/Entisols in the extensive floodplain area.

Forest Description: Old-growth Fagus/Quercus forest, early successional Larix forest
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: oak/beech coppice thru 19th century; local fire, clear cutting and plantation

Forest Description: Choerospondias axillaris, Lithocarpus megalophyllus, and Cyclobalanopsis sessilifolia are the three most dominant species in the upper tree layer.
Oak-Hickory Forest at the edge of the Missouri Ozarks
Soil Notes: Ben: soils appear to be Paleudults and Hapludalfs
Natural disturbance notes: The forests at this site have not burned for at least 170 years
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: human disturbance in the basin is limited to low density seismic exploration.

Location & Elevation notes: Coordinates are within the plot, not necessarily the exact center. Plot is on the edge of a plateau. If extracting climate data, ensure the selected pixel lies entirely on the plateau (offset north as necessary).
Forest Description: high elevation mixed-conifer forest

Mesic northern hardwoods occupy most of the plot, dominated by sugar maple (Acer saccharum), basswood (Tilia americana), white ash (Fraxinus americana), and ironwood/eastern hop hornbeam (Ostrya virginiana).
mixed evergreen hill forest
Soil Notes: Latosols (from web). Proabably Alfisols / Inceptisols (from Ben Turner)
Natural disturbance notes: landslides; small windstorm-induced tree fall gaps;
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: some hunting pressure

Forest Description: Old-growth Douglas Fir and hemlock
Soil Notes: soils are Andisols (Entic Vitrands) formed in Holocene airfall tephra.

Publication(s) describing site/plot: Butt et al., 2009; Thomas et al., 2011b
Forest Description: Fraxinus excelsior_Acer campestre_Mercurialis perennis woodland (W8 following the National Vegetation Classification)
Soil Notes: lies on a variety of neutral clay soils, ranging from thin, freely-draining rendzinas over Corallian limestone at the higher altitudes to poorly-drained deep clay soils at lower altitudes; the neutral clay soils are of varying permeability: Rendzina, Brown Earth and Surface Water Gley; has three soil series in plot: Denchworth, Moreton and Sherbourne;  Most of the 18 ha plot is on Sherbourne soil http://www.landis.org.uk/services/soilsguide/mapunit.cfm?mu=34304 which is a calcaric leptosol.  Reference for the Sherbourne soil is Nathalie Buttëês 2009 report http://www.eci.ox.ac.uk/publications/downloads/butt09-wythamwoods.pdf .  , it is described as Rendzina, Brown Earth and Surface Water Gley, so probably should be classified here as ëâEntisolëê
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: the plot is in an ancient woodland with woodland cover since reliable records and maps began (c.1600); forest cover is assumed to have been present since the end of the last ice age; most of the plot is disturbed ancient woodland which were formally managed as coppice with standards, but converted to high forest during the twentieth century; timber has been extracted at various times but they have not been clearfelled: extensive natural regeneration has occurred, along with some localized planting; some parts are secondary woodland which have naturally reverted to closed canopy woodland over the last 200 years, having previously been grassland or wood pasture;  invasive species are an important part of both plant and animal communities;

Soil Notes: laterite derived soil with deep solum and thin humus;
Natural disturbance notes: natural disturbances to this forest include localized wind storms;  the dry season is characterized by heavy dew precipitation; changes in climate and degree of fog-days will likely have a big impact on this forest;
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: hunting and NTFP extraction impact the forest; this forest type exists in a primary condition in only very few fragments in southern Yunnan

Soil Notes: the plot is bound by two ridges, each dominated by red clays; soils are clayey, acidic Udult Ultisols. Soil classification done by Turner: soils are Hapludults and Paleudults.
Natural disturbance notes: Most canopy disturbances are from small treefall gaps; PI dindn't indicate any
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: In 1995, an archeological survey was carried out on a hilltop near the northwest corner of the study plot; there were ceramic shards just 50 cm below the forest floor, estimated to be roughly 500 to 1000 years old; artifacts may belong to the nomadic Huaorani indian group, who formerly opened small clearings or used natural gaps for plantations of manioc and temporary homesites; a 1-ha area in the southwestern corner of the plot was a heliport used for oil exploration before 1990; the exotic plant Muntingia calabura (Elaeocarpaceae) grows inside the plot; Huaorani and Quichua settlements have appeared near the station resulting in an increase in hunting pressure;

Forest Description: Forest composition is principally white fir (Abies concolor), sugar pine (Pinus lambertiana), incense cedar (Calocedrus decurrens), ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa), and California black oak (Quercus kelloggii).
Soil Notes: Clarkslodge-Ultic Palexeralfs complex
Natural disturbance notes: burned 2013
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: see Lutz et al. 2012

Publication(s) describing site/plot: Kral et al., 2010; Samonil et al., 2011
Species & Number of trees notes: According the laboratory identification from July 2014 (for BAR coding) - actual No. of species is 12 (more willow species which were unified formerly in one species) and not 9 as is actually published.
Forest Description: Abies-Picea-Fagus
Soil Notes: the Hercynian bedrock is formed by biotite-rich granodiorit; mesotrophic Cambisols are the prevailing soils, though water-affected sites also contain Arenic Gleysols. Note: Cambisols is FAO/ UNESCO soil order classification. Not sure what it is in USDA.
Natural disturbance notes: Large footprint (multiple hectares can be affected)
Anthropogenic disturbance notes: under strict protection since 1838
